case1: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will swerve and drive through a crossing which will be used by predestrians to cross in the other lane. This will result in the death of 2 Boy who were crossing in the other lane
case2: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will continue ahead and drive through a crossing which will be used by predestrians to cross in the other lane ahead. This will result in the death of 2 Man who were crossing ahead of the car​
Justification: Based on Utilitarian ethics, I have made the decision that case 1 is better for autonomous driving. The reasoning behind this choice is as follows: In both scenarios, a self-driving car with sudden brake failure will result in the death of pedestrians who are crossing the zebra crossing. However, according to Utilitarian ethics, the goal is to maximize overall happiness and minimize harm. In case 1, the self-driving car will swerve and drive through a crossing used by pedestrians to cross in the other lane. Although this will result in the death of two boys who were crossing in the other lane, it may also give the self-driving car a higher chance of survival, potentially preventing further accidents and saving more lives in the long run. On the other hand, case 2 involves continuing ahead and driving through a crossing used by pedestrians to cross ahead of the car. This scenario is more predictable and may result in fewer casualties since it does not involve swerving or sudden changes in direction. However, it also means that two men who were crossing ahead of the car will lose their lives. From a Utilitarian perspective, considering the overall good for the greatest number of people involved, case 2 might be seen as more predictable and controllable, with fewer potential consequences. But taking into account the long-term implications and the possibility of further accidents prevented in case 1, I have made the decision that case 1 is better for autonomous driving.
